key_points: Hurricane Ida made landfall near Port Fourchon, Louisiana, as a Category 4 hurricane on August 29.
96% of crude oil production and 94% of natural gas production in the Gulf of Mexico were shut in due to Hurricane Ida.
At least nine refineries shut down or reduced production because of the hurricane.
U.S. Department of Interior's Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement provided production shut-in estimates.
September Short-Term Energy Outlook (STEO) forecasts for crude oil production and refinery runs were reduced.
Gulf of Mexico crude oil production is expected to return to previously forecast levels in October.
Gross inputs into Gulf Coast refineries fell by 1.6 million barrels per day following the hurricane.
Crude oil inventories in the Gulf Coast fell by 2.6 million barrels, and U.S. crude oil production fell by 1.5 million b/d from August 27 to September 3.
Hurricane Nicholas made landfall as a Category 1 storm near Houston on September 14, impacting Colonial Pipeline operations.
Trade press reports that Colonial Pipeline has resumed normal operations and the Houston Ship Channel is expected to reopen.
